Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Cluster Algebras Approach to Poisson-Lie Groups and Higher Genus Directed Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research builds upon PIs' previous collaboration on applications of Poisson geometry to cluster algebras. In the current project we will undertake a systematic study of multiple cluster structures in coordinate rings of a number of varieties of importance in algebraic geometry, representation theory and mathematical physics and study an interaction between corresponding cluster algebras. Important examples include simple Lie groups, homogeneous spaces, configuration spaces of points, and are related to discrete and continuous integrable systems. The problems to be considered include cluster structures on simple Lie groups compatible with Poisson-Lie structures associated with the Belavin-Drinfeld classification, inverse problems for directed nets on surfaces of higher genus, continuous limits for directed networks with applications to moduli spaces of flat connections and growth rate classification of cluster algebras.

The rapid development of the cluster algebra theory in recent years revealed relations between cluster algebras and a variety of areas including, among others, commutative and non-commutative algebraic geometry, quiver representations and Teichmuller theory. The proposed research is linked to the development of undergraduate and graduate courses and research projects. Synergistic activities are planned with the goal to promote inter-institutional and inter-departmental cooperation, to attract graduate students from underrepresented groups and with diverse educational backgrounds, and, through a community outreach, at the early exposure of high school students to mathematical research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The notion of cluster algebra was introduced by S.Fomin and A.Zelevinnsky for the purpose of study the construction of canonical bases in representation theory. From the very early days, cluster algebras appear to be useful tool in many different areas of mathematics.

In this project we investigate the connection of cluster algebras and
1) two dimensional surfaces

2) Poisson-Lie brackets on simple Lie groups

3) discrete integrable systems

Any two-dimensional surface can be equipped with a complex structure. The appropriate complex structure is not unique. The set of all possible complex structures forms the moduli space which is a key object in algebraic geometry and mathematical physics. Different complex structures can be parametrized using special collection of  parameters. Particular choice of parameters (coordinates of the moduli space) is important since some phenomena look simpler if appropriate coordinates are chosen. One of the way (shear coordinates) assigns a number (weight) to any edge of triangulation of the surface. When triangulation is changed then edge weights are changed by the rule satisfying cluster algebra axioms.
Corresponding class of cluster algebras is very special in the theory of cluster algebras. For instance, it has only finitely many exchange matrices. We described all cluster algebras having such property. Based on the obtained result we were also able to obtain the classification of cluster algebras by the growth rate. The growth rate shows how fast the number of different clusters obtained from the initial cluster by doing definite number of mutations grows with this number of mutations. This divides all cluster algebras in tame and wild cases.

The second direction of research is devoted to Poisson-Lie point of view. Lie groups are varieties that have group structures (its elements can be multiplied by each other  as, for instance,  rotations in 3d space). A Poisson structure is an engine that allows to transform any function on a variety into a motion law, where the chosen function plays the role of the energy of the motion (hamiltonian). A Poisson structure on a Lie group is called Poisson-Lie if it behaves nicely with respect to the group multiplication. Poisson-Lie structures appear naturally in many problems of mathematical physics. Some important subclass of Poisson-Lie brackets for basic Lie groups (simple Lie groups) was classified in 1982 by Belavin and Drinfeld. We conjectured that for any Poisson-Lie structure from Belvin-Drinfeld classification there is a compatible cluster structure in the coordinate ring of the Lie group.  This allows to construct algebraic coordinates on the Lie group where the Poisson-Lie structure looks particularly simple. Moreover, we are able to construct simultaneously many such particularly simple coordinates at once. These explicit coordinates are important since they allow to simplify calculations in many problems of Poisson Geometry/Mathematical Physics, for instance, to quantize the corresponding Lie group with respect to the chosen Poisson-Lie bracket.

Finally, the third research direction is devoted to application of cluster algebra theory to discrete dynamical system. The most interesting example is the pentagram map that transforms an n-gon in the plane into another n-gon.  The map was introduced by R.Schwartz. Despite the simple looking transformation law this map reveals a deep connection with interesting dynamical systems (Beauville system). Therefore, its dynamical properties were studied. We managed to show using cluster algebra approach that this dynamical system has many conserved quantities (is completely integrable). Moreover, this result can be generalized to n-gons in higher dimensions and to toric dimer configurations.
